Award.AwardTitle: UBM-Institutional: Integrated Undergraduate Research Experiences in Biological and Mathematical Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Integrated Undergraduate Research Experience at the Interface of Biology and Mathematics program aims to promote broader access to cross-disciplinary education in biology and mathematics with an emphasis on undergraduate research, and to strengthen the culture and academic foundation of interdisciplinary biology-mathematics education. To meet these goals it is 1) supporting four cohorts of eight undergraduate students through a two-year research immersion program involving active mentoring and collaborative learning on original research projects in the key biology-mathematics research areas of quantitative ecology, environmental health and freshwater biogeochemistry; and 2) developing new curricular components to facilitate flexible undergraduate biology-mathematics training, including both an interdisciplinary Certificate Program in Quantitative Biology, and a research-oriented biomathematics specialization within the Mathematics major.

The selected research themes, which emphasize aquatic ecology, are dynamic and of topical interest, and closely match the core interests and expertise of participating faculty within the College of Letters and Science and the newly established School of Freshwater Sciences. Students begin their research immersion with a mathematical modeling course sequence, and a parallel research seminar in which they study increasingly open-ended biological research questions, and learn relevant laboratory techniques. In their second year, cohorts investigate research questions within the key research themes, under the joint mentoring of mathematics and biology faculty. The curricular program is strongly connected to the research immersion, in order to motivate student participation in interdisciplinary learning opportunities both inside and outside of the typical classroom. Further, it is providing participating students with appropriate qualifications that reflect these interdisciplinary skills, and which will be recognized in the context of emerging biomathematics programs. The curricular program also is serving to identify, motivate and train future professionals with a skill set that is highly relevant to national interests in restoring and maintaining the health of the Great Lakes region.

The UBM research program is building on a pilot biology-mathematics undergraduate research program at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM), and serving as a model to extend and encourage undergraduate research within interdisciplinary education at UWM. The program is also strengthening teaching and research collaborations among the Departments of Biological Sciences, Mathematical Sciences and the School of Freshwater Sciences, as well as supporting the long term plans of the institution as a whole. Research outcomes are being published in formats accessible by the scientific community as well as by non-scientists and public-policy decision makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Undergraduate Research in Biology and Mathematics (UBM) institutional program at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) ran from 2011 till 2017 with a UBM-group program preceding it from 2008 to 2011. Altogether 56 supported students in eight cohorts completed the program with many more associated with it and benefitting from the developed modelling course sequence and extended opportunities it afforded to our undergraduate students and graduate students who acted as mentors for our cohorts. 

Our key objective was to involve groups of students (made up of an equal number of biology and math majors) in original interdisciplinary research projects as part of a two-year research immersion program. In their first year of involvement students took an intensive mathematical modeling course sequence that was developed for this purpose, and that has since become a popular choice, part of our standard offering. In this sequence and the accompanying research seminar students were exposed to the newest results in science, and have gained the necessary mathematical and computational skills to understand and investigate complex biological systems. After the first two semesters students spent a summer and the next academic year on working on the research projects and presenting their results at various conferences. Many of the research projects were connected to freshwater ecology and had direct societal relevance given our location on the shores of Lake Michigan. Students also worked on projects in other areas, e.g., simulating and modeling the behavior of protein hydrogels, assessing epigenetic effects in zebrafish, investigating causes and mechanisms of cell death and looking at patterns of bat emergence in a Southeastern Wisconsin Bat Hibernaculum.  Attending conferences and presenting their research were transformational experiences for many of our students which gave extra motivation and drive to continue and extend their research. Our student were competitive at the national level which is reflected in the undergraduate presentation awards they earned at national conferences. The substantial time spent together with their fellow students and mentors helped build cohesion and a strong support structure which was a key element in the program’s success. Professors, scientists and graduate students both in biology and mathematics provided support for all aspects of the research program as well as for course and career planning. Our students were encouraged to apply for various opportunities after their UBM participation ended, and they took full advantage of them.

We recruited a diverse group of undergraduate students to participate in UBM, not just the very best students. Many of the students were unsure about their career direction when they joined the program. About a third of them started their mathematics classes at UWM at or below the lowest credit-bearing math class, while about an equal number started at the precalculus and the calculus level. Remarkably, all of our students have finished, or are on track to finish their bachelor’s degree, many with extra majors and minors. Thirteen students finished (or are in the process of completing) a Master’s or an MBA program, while twelve are in PhD or MD or Veterinary programs. (These results are far above the institutional average at UWM.) We are especially proud of the several first generation and minority students who completed or currently are in advance degree granting programs as a result of the motivation and mentoring the UBM program provided. It is worth noting that many of our students became strong mentors themselves who help and support undergraduate students at UWM or in their current institutions.

The UBM program strengthened teaching and research collaborations among the Departments of Biological Sciences, Mathematical Sciences and the School of Freshwater Science at a time when diminishing resources put a strain on our institution’s operation. The curricular components developed during UBM became integral parts of the educational experience at UWM. The program proved that interdisciplinary undergraduate research is feasible and is an extremely valuable motivator for student success.

The vertical integration and strong mentoring components of the program required substantial amount of faculty time, but were very important (in fact, we believe, essential) components of the program, and while the outcomes of the program are very strong, the model if followed require allocated resources. Due to the continually tightening state funding and budget constraints at our institution, without external resources the program could only continue at a lower intensity.
